bestBHT.bht: Apart from Jesus, we have no power to bear fruit, to do anything spiritually or acceptably. Without Him, we can do nothing. As a branch separated from the vine withers and dies, so we are nothing without our union with Jesus. Our fruitfulness is solely attributed to Him and His grace, not our own efforts or power. We must abide in Him, seek strength and grace from Him alone, for apart from Jesus, we can do nothing.

Henry Alford: It is he, that beareth much fruit.
Because union with Me is the sole efficient cause of fruit being produced.
You having no power to do any thing, to bring any thing to perfection, to do any of those things which belong to that which ye are, separate from Me.
Albert Barnes: Without me ye can do nothing."
To him is due all the praise for all the good works the Christian performs.
The reason why others fail of being holy is because they are unwilling to look to him, and seek grace and strength from him who alone is able to give it.
Marvin Vincent: Without me [χωρις εμου] . Properly, apart from me. So Rev. Compare John 1:3; Ephesians 2:12.
John Calvin: Without me you can do nothing. [...] we bear no fruit that is good and acceptable to God, for we are unable to do anything good.

But Christ, on the other hand, declares that we can do nothing of ourselves. The branch, he says, beareth not fruit of itself; and, therefore, he not only extols the aid of his co-operating grace, but deprives us entirely of all power but what he imparts to us.
Christ does not explain what the branch has naturally, before it become united to the vine, but rather means that we begin to become branches at the time when we are united to him.
Philip Schaff: He that abideth in me, and I in him, the same beareth much fruit; because apart from me ye can do nothing.
The transition from John 15:4 to John 15:5...a transition from the principle to its application to men.
The words ‘ye can do nothing’ refer to the efforts of one already a believer.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus repeats and applies the metaphor of verse John 15:1."
Apart from me... There is nothing for a broken off branch to do but wither and die."
For the cosmic relation of Christ see John 1:3 (χωρις αυτου).
John Gill: he that abideth in me, and I in him; which is the case of all that are once in Christ, and he in them."
for without me ye can do nothing; nothing that is spiritually good; no, not anything at all, be it little or great, easy or difficult to be performed.
the fruitfulness of a believer is to be ascribed to Christ, and his grace, and not to the free will and power of man.
John Wesley: I am the vine, ye are the branches."
Our Lord in this whole passage speaks of no branches but such as are, or at least were once, united to him by living faith.

bhtAttempts.bht: Apart from Jesus, we have no power to bear fruit, to do anything spiritually or acceptably. We are unable to bring anything to perfection, do anything that belongs to our identity apart from Him. Without Him, we can do nothing. As a branch separated from the vine withers and dies, so we are nothing without our union with Jesus. Our fruitfulness is solely attributed to Him and His grace, not our own efforts or power. We must abide in Him, seek strength and grace from Him alone, for apart from Jesus, we can do nothing.

Apart from Jesus, we have no power to bear fruit, to do anything spiritually or acceptably. Without Him, we can do nothing. As a branch separated from the vine withers and dies, so we are nothing without our union with Jesus. Our fruitfulness is solely attributed to Him and His grace, not our own efforts or power. We must abide in Him, seek strength and grace from Him alone, for apart from Jesus, we can do nothing.

Without Jesus, we have no power to do anything, to bring anything to perfection, or to do anything that belongs to our true nature. We are spiritually disconnected and apart from Him, we can do nothing. Apart from Him, there is nothing for us but withering and dying. Our fruitfulness is not due to our own efforts but solely dependent on our union with Jesus, the true vine. We must abide in Him, continually seeking grace and strength from Him, for without Him, we are unable to do anything good. It is only when we are united to Him that we begin to bear fruit. Our fruitfulness is not the result of our own free will or power, but is to be ascribed to Christ and His grace. We are the branches, and it is through our living faith in Christ that we are united to Him and bear fruit.

Apart from Jesus, we can do nothing. We have no power to bring anything to completion or do what belongs to our nature. We are spiritually disconnected from Him, and without Him, there is no purpose or productivity. Our fruitfulness is solely dependent on our union with Jesus, the true vine. It is through Him that we find strength, grace, and the ability to bear fruit. Our own efforts are futile, but when we abide in Jesus, we are empowered to live a fruitful life.

Apart from Jesus, we can do nothing; our efforts are futile. Only through union with Him can we bear much fruit. We are unable to do anything good without His grace and strength. Without Him, we are spiritually disconnected, like a broken-off branch that withers and dies. Our fruitfulness is solely attributed to Christ, not our own power or will. It is through our abiding in Him that we are united and empowered to bear fruit, relying completely on His co-operating grace.
